qas.question: Are children or adolescents more likely to question assertions and less likely to accept facts?
Is not dating until a certain age a common sense or culturally-relative standard?
Is refraining from touching a hot stoce a common sense or culturally-relative standard?

context: Compared to children, <a0_0>adolescents<a0_0/> are more likely to question others' assertions, and less likely to accept facts as absolute truths. Through experience outside the family circle, they learn that rules they were taught as absolute are in fact relativistic. They begin to differentiate between rules instituted out of <a2_0>common sense<a2_0/>—not touching a hot stove—and those that are based on <a1_0>culturally-relative<a1_0/> standards (codes of etiquette, not dating until a certain age), a delineation that younger children do not make. This can lead to a period of questioning authority in all domains.
